title: How to Fix a Loose Tooth

steps.title: See your dentist for a cleaning.
steps.content: See your dentist for a cleaning. You should see your dentist at least twice a year if you don't have dental issues, like gingivitis. [2] X Research source Your dentist and dental hygienist will deep clean your teeth, taking care to deep clean the pockets that otherwise can't be cleaned by brushing or flossing. [3] X Expert Source Tu Anh Vu, DMD Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 20 May 2020. Calculus gets under the gums creating a constant deposit of aggressive bacteria, which leads to inflamed gums, gum recession and bone loss. If you have gingivitis or periodontitis, talk with your dentist about getting more frequent cleanings.

steps.title: Brush your teeth correctly.
steps.content: Brush your teeth correctly. [4] X Expert Source Tu Anh Vu, DMD Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 20 May 2020. Take a toothbrush with soft bristles and set it against your gums at a 45-degree angle. Brush the outer surfaces, inner surfaces, and chewing surfaces of your teeth using small short strokes. Brush each surface about 10 times using gentle pressure. Don't forget to hold the brush vertically and brush up-and-down to clean the inside surfaces of your front teeth. Brush your tongue, spit out the toothpaste, and leave the foam in your mouth without rinsing. [5] X Research source Brush your teeth and tongue with a tartar-control toothpaste at least twice a day. Leaving the toothbrush foam on your teeth gives the minerals some time to be absorbed into your teeth, especially if you use a fluoride toothpaste which has more than 1200ppm.

steps.title: Floss daily.
steps.content: Floss daily. [6] X Expert Source Tu Anh Vu, DMD Board Certified Dentist Expert Interview. 20 May 2020. Unwind about 18 inches of dental floss and wind most of it around the middle finger of one hand with the rest around the middle finger of your other hand. Firmly hold the floss between your thumb and forefinger. Guide the floss between each tooth, gently using a back and forth and side to side motion to gently move the floss between your teeth without causing it to snap. Be sure to rub each side of each tooth before unwinding more floss and moving to the next tooth. Or, you can use a "water pick" (a handheld device that steadily sprays water between your teeth and gums). Consider using a "water pick" if you don't like flossing, have braces, have bridges, or can't floss. Fill it with a 50:50 solution of mouthwash and water to increase the antibacterial protection.

steps.title: Use antibiotics or antiseptic rinses.
steps.content: Use antibiotics or antiseptic rinses. Your dentist might prescribe one of these to use daily if you have gum disease. You may need to take oral antibiotics like low-dose doxycycline to control bacteria that damages the gums, which may last for up to three months. Or, your dentist could recommend that you use an antimicrobial rinse as a mouthwash. [7] X Research source You may be told to place antiseptic chips or gel packets in the deep pockets between your gums and teeth. If you are not too handy ask a member of your household to help you, or schedule an appointment with your dentist. These can control harmful bacteria.

steps.title: Use herbs to massage your gums.
steps.content: Use herbs to massage your gums. Natural anti-inflammatory herbs and oils can treat bacteria, reducing gum inflammation. Try gently massaging your gums with one of these to get the following benefits: Turmeric: anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antibiotic. [8] X Research source Hu P, Huang P, Chen MW., Curcumin attenuates cyclooxygenase-2 expression via inhibition of the NF-κB pathway in lipopolysaccharide-stimulated human gingival fibroblasts. Cell Biol Int. 2013 May;37(5):443-8. Aloe Vera: anti-inflammatory, which is good for those who suffer from gingivitis or periodontis. Mustard oil: antibiotic, anti-inflammatory. [9] X Research source Komorowski RC, Torneck CD, Hu JW. Neurogenic inflammation and tooth pulp innervation pattern in sympathectomized rats. J Endod. 1996 Aug;22(8):414-7. Peppermint oil: antibiotic, anti-inflammatory, breath freshener. [10] X Research source Duss C, Lang NP, Cosyn J, Persson GR. A randomized, controlled clinical trial on the clinical, microbiological, and staining effects of a novel 0.05% chlorhexidine/herbal extract and a 0.1% chlorhexidine mouthrinse adjunct to periodontal surgery. J Clin Periodontol. 2010 Nov;37(11):988-97. Oregano oil: antibiotic, immune-booster. [11] X Research source Ok E, Adanir N, Ozturk T. Antibacterial and smear layer removal capability of oregano extract solution. Eur J Dent. 2015 Jan-Mar;9(1):20-4. Amla (Indian gooseberry): anti-inflammatory, antioxidants, high levels of vitamin C. [12] X Research source Singh A, Purohit B. Tooth brushing, oil pulling and tissue regeneration: A review of holistic approaches to oral health. J Ayurveda Integr Med. 2011 Apr;2(2):64-8. Sea salt: prevents bacterial growth and tightens gums around the teeth. [13] X Research source Sun XW, Sun GL, Xiao LJ. [Evaluation of gingival inflammation related to different retraction agents]. [Article in Chinese].Hua Xi Kou Qiang Yi Xue Za Zhi. 2008 Feb;26(1):53-5.

steps.title: Limit sugars and processed starches.
steps.content: Limit sugars and processed starches. Bacteria feeds off of sugar, so reduce your sugar intake to keep bacteria from thriving. [14] X Research source Avoid processed and pre-packaged foods, and sweetened drinks. Read labels and avoid the product if sugar, high-fructose corn syrup, cane syrup, or another sweetener is listed as one of the top five ingredients. Reduce or avoid the following, which can have an even worse effect if you are consuming more than one of these items on a regular basis: Pre-packaged snacks, crackers, chips. Breads or cakes. Soda, fruit drinks, sweet tea.

steps.title: Use honey or stevia in place of sugar.
steps.content: Use honey or stevia in place of sugar. When you do eat something sweet, use honey which has antibacterial properties and stevia. Stevia is an herb that is 200 times sweeter than sugar and has no calories. [15] X Trustworthy Source American Diabetes Association Health-based nonprofit focused on preventing and researching diabetes Go to source Avoid using artificial sweeteners like aspartame which can cause glucose intolerance (prediabetes) by changing the balance of your gut bacteria. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Pay attention to the amount of citrus you eat.
steps.content: Pay attention to the amount of citrus you eat. Eat citrus fruits in moderation and be sure to rinse out your mouth with water and never brush immediately after eating. This will decrease the amount of acid in your mouth. The natural sugars in fruit, fructose, don't feed bacteria and are not found in high levels in fresh fruit like apples, pears, or peaches. Don't be afraid to eat fresh fruits. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Chew your meals slowly and drink water.
steps.content: Chew your meals slowly and drink water. Take the time to chew each bite completely so that your mouth produces saliva. [18] X Research source Saliva can naturally remineralize your teeth during meals and the more you chew the more saliva will be released. You should also drink 6 to 8 eight-ounce glasses of pure water a day. You don't need to drink mineral water; get your minerals from your diet instead. It's fine to drink well or tap water, which contain minerals unique to your area. [19] X Research source Tap water in much of the US is treated with fluoride to help prevent tooth decay. Though many people choose bottled water over tap water, most bottled water does not have much (if any) fluoride. If your water is "de-ionized, purified, demineralized, or distilled," then any naturally occurring fluoride has been removed. [20] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source [21] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Drinking water is simply a way to stay hydrated without ingesting substances that damage your teeth. If you eat sour acidic foods, chew even slower to increase the amount of saliva you make.

steps.title: Take a mineral supplement.
steps.content: Take a mineral supplement. Your multivitamin should contain minerals, especially calcium and magnesium. Magnesium is important in preventing calcium loss, which can weaken your bones and teeth. Try to get at least 1000 mg of calcium and 300 to 400 mg of magnesium every day if you do not consume products such as milk, cheese or yogurt. Otherwise you will have an increased rate of calculus deposits. If you're a man over 71 or a woman over 51, try to get 1200 mg of calcium every day. Children taking children's vitamins have different magnesium needs. From birth to 3 years old, they need 40 to 80 mg a day; for kids between three and six years old, they need 120 mg a day; and for kids up to 10 years old, they need 170 mg a day.

steps.title: Get more vitamin D.
steps.content: Get more vitamin D. Vitamin D and calcium work together to strengthen your bones and teeth. Vitamin D can also help destroy bacteria that causes dental decay. Try to get about 600 IU (international units) of vitamin D every day. Adults over 70 years should bet 800 IU every day. Or, you can spend about 10–15 minutes every third day in the afternoon sun without sunscreen. Expose your arms, legs, and back, if you can. To get vitamin D from your diet eat foods rich in vitamin D. These include: [22] X Research source Fish (salmon, snapper, whitefish, mackerel). Soymilk fortified with vitamin D. Coconut milk. Cow's milk. Eggs. Yogurt.
